Here are some statistics and sources specific to Canada regarding the experiences of women and underrepresented groups in the energy, clean energy, and climate sectors:

1. According to a 2019 report by the Canadian Energy Regulator (CER), women made up only 27% of the energy sector workforce in Canada.
Source: <https://www.cer-rec.gc.ca/nrg/ntgrtd/ftr/2019/wrkfrc-eng.html>
2. A 2019 study by the Brookfield Institute for Innovation + Entrepreneurship found that only 13% of cleantech patents in Canada had a female inventor.
Source: <https://brookfieldinstitute.ca/reports/gender-innovation-cleantech/>
3. In 2020, the Canadian Association of Women in Construction (CAWIC) reported that only 12% of construction workers in Canada were women.
Source: <https://cawic.ca/about-us/>
4. A 2019 report by the Canadian Climate Law Centre found that Indigenous and racialized women are disproportionately impacted by the impacts of climate change in Canada.
Source: <https://www.climatelawcentre.ca/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/The-Faces-of-Climate-Impact-Women-in-Canada-2019.pdf>

These are just a few examples and you can find more specific data and statistics by searching for relevant studies, reports, and organizations such as the Canadian Centre for Gender, Diversity, and Inclusion in Energy (CanGEA), the Women in Energy Network (WEN) Canada, and others.
